sentence: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 were struggling to climb out of negative territory at midday on Monday as the impact from Hurricane Harvey split buyers and sellers between the home improvement and insurance sectors, while the Nasdaq maintained a measurable lead over its benchmark counterparts on gains in the healthcare and technology sectors.
Energy futures were also diverging with gas futures trading considerably higher, but West Texas Intermediate crude oil prices down more than 3%.
With Houston-area refiners shut down, as much as 2 million barrels per day is coming off line.
This is expected to dramatically impact the demand for unrefined crude.
Among Dow components, Home Depot ( HD ) shares are 1.20% higher while shares of Travelers are leading decliners with a loss of nearly 3%.

The fallout from Harvey overshadowed Monday's economic data which included a wider-than-expected goods trade deficit of $65.1 billion, and unexpected increase in the Dallas Fed manufacturing index to 17.0 from July's 16.8.

European shares continue to be weighed down by the rapid appreciation of the euro, currently flirting with the key psychological level of 1.20 against the dollar after European Central Bank president Mario Draghi refrained from jawboning the currency lower last week.
The euro's impact on exporters was heaviest among German auto makers and French luxury brands, while energy shares are trading lower in sympathy with their U.S. counterparts.
Crude oil was down $1.58 to $46.29 per barrel.
Natural gas was up $0.04 to $2.96 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was up $13.90 to $1,311.80 an ounce, while silver was up $0.31 to $17.44 an ounce.
Copper was up $0.03 to $3.09 per pound.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund was down 2.97% to $9.46 with the United States Natural Gas Fund was up 1.01% to $6.56.
Amongst precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was up 2.56% to 24.01 while SPDR Gold Shares were up 1.18% to $124.18.
The iShares Silver Trust was up 1.86% to $16.41.

Here's where the markets stand at mid-day:

NYSE Composite Index was down 17.93 points (-0.15%) to 11,793.95

Dow Jones Industrial Index was down 13.63 points (-0.06%) to 21,799.60

S&P 500 was down 0.56 points (-0.02%) to 2,442.49

Nasdaq Composite Index was up 18.63 points (+0.30%) to 6,284.19

DAX was down 44.47 points (-0.37%) to 12,123.47

CAC 40 was down 24.58 points (-0.48%) to 5,079.75

Nikkei 225 was down 2.71 points (-0.01%) to 19,449.90

Hang Seng Index was up 15.13 points (+0.05%) to 27,863.29

Shanghai China Composite Index was up 31.13 points (+0.93%) to 3,362.65

NYSE Energy Sector Index was down 67.59 points (-0.68%) to 9,906.19

NYSE Financial Sector Index was down 34.13 points (-0.45%) to 7,514.63

NYSE Healthcare Sector Index was up 44.13 points (+0.33%) to 13,526.98

(+) MXPT (+147.87%) To be acquired by Valassis for $95 million

(+) FSNN (+73.99%) Agreed to buy Birch Communications cloud and business operations unit in all-stock deal

(+) KITE (+28.36%) Agrees to be acquired by Gilead ( GILD ) for $11.9 billion
